title: Scenario: Dave
body: Here we'll meet Dave, who cares for his father Terry, who had a stroke.
instruction: Click or tap the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody: Dave is an recent university graduate living in Dublin and is currently unemployed. He receives a call from his sister who tells them that their father, Terry, fell when he was at the supermarket and he was brought to hospital by ambulance. She is down as his emergency contact but she can't get away from work so Dave goes to the hospital. While talking to the doctor, he discovers that his father has had a stroke. Terry is started on new medications and stays in hospital for a few weeks for rehabilitation. Initially he has some problems swallowing but this improves. However, Terry's recovery is not complete, he still has some weakness in his right arm and leg and some vision issues. Dave is present during some, but not all of the conversations that his father has with the various medical professionals, including the dietician. On returning home, Terry is now unable to drive and Dave decides to stay with his father to help with his rehabilitation and diet. Their budget is limited but the dietician said that his father's diet is really important if he wants to prevent another stroke.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
After completing this lesson, you will be able to:
  • Describe some of the barriers that prevent people from changing their diet.
  • Work out the calories and macronutrients in any recipe.
  • Find recipes online, compare them to your own requirements and alter them as necessary.
  • Create a meal plan for a week that meets your energy and nutrient requirements.
  • Create a shopping list for your groceries.

_graphic.alt: Image of a cartoon man thinking.
Image of a woman choosing between fruit and pastries.

title: Barriers to Changing Your Diet
body:
There are a number of barriers when anyone tries to change their diet:
  • We tend to eat what is put in front of us, even if it causes us to feel over-full.
  • We tend to overestimate how much food we need to feel full.
  • We think we don't have enough time to cook or meal plan.
  • We think that the new food we eat won't be tasty or won't satisfy us.
  • We become overwhelmed by how much there is to know about nutrition and diets.
  • We receive conflicting advice about what diets are best and what we need to do to lose weight.

title: Why Learn About Meal Planning?
body:
Dietary habits are difficult to change and meal planning is a very important tool that can help you start and maintain a healthy diet.

The benefits of meal planning include the following:
  • It is easier to budget.
  • It is easier to control portion sizes.
  • It is better than exercise planning for sustained weight loss.
  • It can enable meal variety.
  • It can allow space for treats while staying within your energy needs for the week.
  • It simplifies maintaining a healthy diet.

_graphic.alt: Image of a weekly meal plan surrouned by containers with various meals.
Image of a calculator.

title: Adding Up Your Energy and Macros
body:
Calculations can seem like a very difficult part of meal planning. It takes time to work out whether you are meeting your macronutrient needs and not exceeding your energy needs.

As discussed previously, we tend to overestimate how much food we need and then also tend to eat all of what is put in front of us. So, without these calculations, it is very difficult to tell if you are exceeding your energy needs.

However, the meal plans and resources included in this course will help and many online recipes include their energy and macronutrient content which also helps a lot!

title: The Importance of Mindset
body:
There will always be an element of compromise when starting a new diet. You may not be able to eat as much of your favourite foods as you would like, or, particularly at the beginning, the portion-sizes may be a little small for you to feel full.

Mindset is key. If you keep 'healthiness' in mind, this can do a lot to help you get through the first few weeks.

_graphic.alt: Cartoon image of a calm person's brain.
Image of the meal planning steps. One, meal frequency. Two, energy and macros. Three, energy per meal. Four, find and alter recipes.

title: Meal Planning Steps
body:
1. Decide on your meal frequency.
  2. Work out your energy and macronutrient requirements for each day.
  3. Work out how much energy you want to consume at each meal.
  4. Find recipes and alter them as necessary to meet your requirements.

title: Meal Frequency
body:
The dietary habits of many cultures are centered on having three meals a day plus snacks. However, it is up to you how you organise your own diet. You can have three larger meals per day and no snacks, or six smaller meals per day.

Regardless of when you eat your meals, focus on nutrient-dense foods and stay within your energy needs.

As it is the most common, the meal plans in this course are focused on three meals per day, plus snacks. The main meals contain around 1500kcal per day and the snacks contain around 250kcal each. This should give space for mixing and matching and adding extra snacks or meals for higher energy needs.

However, rather than adding extra meals, it is often easier to increase the amount of whatever ingredient you need to meet your macros: the carbohydrate source, the protein source, or the amount of olive oil.
Click the image to learn about intermittent fasting!

_graphic.alt: Image of a blank weekly meal plan.

_items.title: Intermittent Fasting
_items.body:
There is good evidence that intermittent fasting has a number of health benefits, particularly on cardiovascular health. There are many ways to do intermittent fasting:
  • Eating fewer calories on two or three days each week.
  • Eating fewer calories every second day.
  • Only eating within an eight hour window every day.
Explaining intermittent fasting in greater detail is beyond the scope of this course but here are some resources that can get you started if you're interested:
  • Intermittent Fasting: What is it, and how does it work? (Johns Hopkins Medicine)
  • Intermittent Fasting 101 — The Ultimate Beginner’s Guide (healthline)
  • What is intermittent fasting? Does it have health benefits? (Mayo Clinic)
  • Pros and Cons of 5 Intermittent Fasting Methods (healthline)
  • The Beginner’s Guide to Intermittent Fasting (James Clear)
  • What Is Intermittent Fasting? (verywellfit)

_graphic.alt: Cartoon image of a man pushing the food for the day into an eight hour period on a clock.

instruction: Click the image to find out more about meal prep!

_graphic.alt: Image of a blank notepad surrounded by containters with various meals.

_items.title: Meal Prep Resources
_items.body:
If you are interested in learning more about meal prep, visit any of the following resources:
  • How to Meal Prep — A Beginner’s Guide (healthline)
  • A Beginner's Guide to Meal Prep (EatingWell)
  • Meal Prep Recipes (allrecipes)
  • Freezer Meal Recipes (allrecipes)
    • Remember to check the nutritional information of the recipes and compare them to your energy and macronutrient needs.

_graphic.alt: Image of two containers with meals.

title: Meal Prep
body:
Meal prep is any time you cook days in advance of eating the meal and then storing portions of the meal in the fridge or freezer. It is an important tool when starting a new diet and it is very effective when combined with meal planning.

You can cook extra portions of a meal you eat that day, or spend a few hours cooking all of the food for the following few days or week. You can store extra portions beyond your meal plan in the freezer for times when you are unable to cook.

Even if you don't cook the full meals you could cook a large batch of one ingredient that tends to take a long time and have it ready for later meals. For example, you could cook all of the brown rice for various meals.

_graphic.alt: Image of a cartoon woman sitting on a pie chart.

title: Energy Splitting
body:
The next step is working out how much energy you want to consume at each meal. Again there are many possibilities. You could want a small breakfast, a large lunch and large dinner with no snacks. Or a large breakfast, small lunch and medium dinner, plus a snack. It is up to you how you organise your meals.

An alternative to planning this much in advance is to pick out recipes and stop when you are approaching your calorie limit.

title: Finding Recipes
body:
There are many, many places to find recipes. There are recipes included in the resources section of this course, you can find recipes in cook books and thousands if not millions of recipes from various websites and blogs.

A word of warning about online recipes

It is often difficult to tell whether online recipes are healthy or not. Sometimes they can even have the word 'healthy' in the title but have lots of saturated fat or lots of processed ingredients.

Look for recipes that:
  • List both calories and macronutrients.
  • Contain no or very few processed ingredients.
  • Contain no or few ingredients with lots of saturated fat.
  • Contain a few unhealthy ingredients that can be replaced with healthier ones (e.g., replacing butter with oil).
Another thing to note is that low-fat or low-carb recipes are often seen as 'healthy'. However, neither of these comply with the Mediterranean diet. Your meals should be:
  • High in extra-virgin olive oil and low in saturated fat.
  • High in unrefined carbohydrates and low in added sugars.
Sometimes searching for low-cholesterol meals is useful as foods high in cholesterol are often also high in saturated fat. So, low-cholesterol recipes are often also low-saturated fat recipes!
Recipe from Heart UK Website

_items.title: Recipe Websites and Blogs
_items.body:
• Heart UK Healthy Dinner Recipes
  • Healthy Mediterranean Recipes (EatingWell)
  • Delicious magazine Low Fat recipes
  • BBC Food Lean Meat Recipes
  • Mediterranean Diet Meal Plans (EatingWell)

    • Useful Books

    • The Fitness Chef by Graeme Tomlinson: contains excellent comparisons between foods with different nutrient and energy densities.
    • The Mediterranean Diet Cookbook for Beginners by Elena Parvantes: includes a 2 week meal plan and 100 recipes which include energy and macros.
    • The Meal Prep King Plan by John Clark: contains lots of tips about meal prepping, a 21 day meal prep plan and recipes include energy and macros (though not saturated fat).
    • Slimming Eats by Siobhan Wightman: contains over 100 recipes with energy and macros.

_graphic.alt: Image of the Mediterranean Soup recipe from the Heart UK Website.

_items.title: Helpful Websites
_items.body:
Listed below are some websites you can use to work out the calories and macronutrients in various foods.
  • NutritonValue.org's Nutrition Calculator and Recipe Builder

  • fatsecret.com's Food Search

  • WebMD's Food Calculator

_graphic.alt: Image of the verywellfit.com's recipe calculator's output which looks like a nutritional label.

title: Working Out Recipe Macronutrients and Energy
body:
If you find a recipe and want to work out the energy and macronutrients it contains, there are a number of websites that can make your life easier.

For example, verywellfit.com's Recipe Calculator allows you to paste the ingredients of full recipes and it will work out the nutritional information. It works best if you remove words and phrases that describe how the ingredients are prepared, such as diced, sliced, chopped, washed, rinsed, skin removed, shredded, halved, etc.

Unfortunately there is no easy shortcut; there are too many ingredients and they are all too different from each other for there to be an easy rule for calculating the energy and macronutrients in each.

If you don't want to do this step, try to use recipes that have their energy and macronutrients already worked out.

title: Altering Recipes
body:
If you find a recipe online that you want to try, but it contains too many calories, too much saturated fat, or too many processed ingredients you can always swap the ingredients for ones that comply with the Mediterranean diet.

Note that this won't always be possible but there are many substitutions that are easy to make. Sometimes swapping ingredients will require some slightly different cooking methods, for example, a skinless chicken breast may require more oil to fry than a chicken breast with the skin on.

Luckily, you have lots of olive oil!

_graphic.alt: Image of swapping butter for extra-virgin olive oil.

instruction: Click the image to see the shopping list food groups.

_graphic.alt: Image of Dave and Terry shopping.

_items.title: Shopping List Food Groups
_items.body:
When creating a shopping list, organise ingredients under the following headings:
  • Vegetables.
  • Fruit.
  • Bread and Eggs.
  • Protein and Dairy.
  • Tins and Bottles.
  • Spices.
  • Dried and Cereals.
  • Frozen.
There is a handy Shopping List Template available in the resources section on the top right of the screen that can help with this, or you can use a blank sheet of paper, or a program such as Microsoft Word or Excel.

_graphic.alt: Image of a blank shopping list.

title: Creating Shopping Lists
body:
Once you have created your meal plan for the week, the next step is to create a shopping list. Creating a shopping list is really important for a number of reasons:
  1. It makes shopping much less stressful as it requires less thinking.
  2. It helps to prevent buying unhealthy foods.
  3. By grouping similar items together it allows you to get your shopping done efficiently. This also helps when an ingredient is unavilable, you're already in the area where you will find similar ingredients that you can substitute in.
  4. It helps with budgeting as you are much less likely to buy extra 'just in case'.

title: Important Kitchen Tools
body:
There are some kitchen tools that many home cooks do without. The following are some tools that will make cooking a lot easier and more enjoyable.
  1. A digital scales.
  2. A knife sharpener.
  3. Measurings spoons +/- measuring cups.
  4. A measuring jug with easy-to-read measurements.

_graphic.alt: Image of a digital kitchen scales, a knife sharpener, measuring cups and a measuring jug.
Image of a cartoon kitchen.

title: Before You Start Cooking
body:
When cooking a recipe for a first time, read it through and prepare all the ingredients before starting to cook. Preparing ingredients will include things like peeling and cutting vegetables, slicing and removing fat and skin from meat and soaking or rinsing grains and legumes.

This may take slightly longer the first time you prepare the meal but will make the experience far more enjoyable and will allow you more time to taste the food as you go along and add more seasoning if necessary.

Then, the next time, you'll be more aware of how much time you have between steps of the recipe and be able to judge what you should prepare before and what you can prepare as you are cooking.

Sometimes recipes give an estimate of how long it takes to prepare ingredients. These are often a best case scenario and be prepared to double or triple the prep-time, particularly the first time you cook a recipe.

title: Tasks
body:
There is no assessment in this module. Instead you have multiple tasks to do, using the resources included in this course.

Task 1

Fill out the Meal Plan resource with your daily energy needs and macronutrient needs.

Task 2

Create a meal plan for the week using the included meal plan, or use the websites mentioned in this lesson to find your own recipes. Remember to include meal prep and cook some ingredients in advance, or create extra portions for later in the week.

Task 3

Create a shopping list of all the ingredients you will need.

Task 4

Cook and enjoy your meals based on all you have learned about nutrition and the Mediterranean diet!

_graphic.alt: Image of George, Steven, Nuala, Maureen, Jacinta, Trevor, Dave and Terry with the message 'You can do it!'
